text:
- Carolyn Warmus, did you
murder Betty Jeanne Solomon?
CAROLYN WARMUS: Of course not.
Of course not.

- Since 1989, Warmus has
never wavered from her story.

She has researched and filed
for documents and evidence
she says would clear her name.

- There is nothing more
difficult than being

able to show that you're
innocent after you've
been convicted by a jury.

All you can do is try
to show that there were
serious errors in the trial.

Or you can show maybe
that there's new evidence,

and that new evidence
is so important

that it might be
able to show that you
were wrongfully convicted.

- As for parole, she had
her shot for the first time
earlier this year.

She didn't get far
with that, either.

- Why not go before the
board and say, I'm sorry,
I show remorse.

CAROLYN WARMUS:
Well, I mean, I just

feel so strongly that I
want my name back as-- as
much as I can get it back.

I mean, I was an
elementary school teacher.
I was a good person.

I would least like
to go forward with

some sort of a-- a life, and at
least, hopefully not, have a--

a murder conviction on my
record, um, for a murder
that I didn't commit.
